4624.description: An account was successfully logged on.
4624.analyst_summary: Review these logons for unauthorized access, especially during off-hours. Correlate with physical access records, VPN logs, and other related events to validate legitimacy. If multiple logons occur in a short time, investigate potential automated processes or script-based attacks.
detailed_analysis: Identify the logon type to understand the nature of the logon (e.g., Interactive, Network, Remote Interactive). Pay special attention to Remote Interactive logons as they may indicate RDP sessions.

Check the source IP address to determine if the logon originated from a trusted or expected location. Unexpected IP addresses, particularly from foreign or untrusted regions, may indicate unauthorized access.

Correlate with related events such as Event ID 4625 (Failed Logon) or Event ID 4672 (Special Privileges Assigned) to identify suspicious patterns or behaviors that could suggest a compromised account.

Examine the logon time to determine if it occurred during non-business hours. Logons during these times, especially from accounts not typically active during these hours, may require further investigation.
Analyze the account usage history to determine if the logon behavior aligns with the typical activity for the account. Unusual logon types or times could be red flags.
Look for lateral movement by investigating if the logon was followed by access to other systems. This could be indicative of an attacker moving within the network.
Review the privileges assigned to the account during the logon. If special privileges were granted (Event ID 4672), verify the legitimacy of this escalation.
Investigate any concurrent logons from the same account, especially from different geographic locations, as this could indicate account compromise or automated attacks.
Use User Behavior Analytics (UBA) tools to detect deviations from normal user activity, such as logons from new devices or unexpected times.
Check for related logoff events (Event ID 4634) to assess the session duration. Very short or very long sessions may require additional scrutiny.
suggestions: Investigate the source IP address and geolocation to verify if they are consistent with the user’s usual login patterns. Consider blocking suspicious IPs if necessary.
Look for previous failed logon attempts (Event ID 4625) that may indicate a brute-force attack prior to the successful logon.
Audit for any privilege escalation following the logon (Event ID 4672). If special privileges were granted, ensure this was legitimate.
Pay close attention to Remote Interactive logons (Logon Type 10), as they could indicate remote access via RDP, a common attack vector.
Review other authentication events within the same time frame to identify patterns or anomalies that might suggest unauthorized access.
Monitor the actions taken by the user after logging on, such as accessing sensitive files or executing unusual commands.
Correlate the logon event with physical access logs to ensure the user was physically present when the logon occurred.
Set up alerts for logon events that deviate from normal behavior, such as logons during off-hours or from unfamiliar locations.
Look for signs of account compromise, such as simultaneous logons from different locations (impossible travel scenarios).
Investigate related Event IDs such as 4648 (Logon Attempted Using Explicit Credentials), 4672 (Special Privileges Assigned to New Logon), and 4634 (Logoff) to build a timeline of activities.

4625.description: An account failed to log on.
4625.analyst_summary: Check for potential brute force attempts or misconfigured accounts. Analyze the frequency of failures and the originating IPs to detect patterns indicative of an attack. Failed logons from a service account or administrative account warrant immediate investigation.
detailed_analysis: Identify the source IP address and determine if it is internal, external, or from a known suspicious location. Repeated failures from external or unexpected IP addresses may indicate a brute-force attack.
Analyze the account type involved in the failed logon. If the account is a service account or has administrative privileges, this could be a sign of targeted attack.
Correlate this event with successful logon attempts (Event ID 4624) shortly after the failures. A successful logon following multiple failures could indicate a brute-force attack.

Examine the logon type to understand the context of the failure (e.g., Interactive, Network, Remote Interactive). Remote logon attempts (Logon Type 10) are particularly concerning if they fail repeatedly.
Review the timing of the failures to detect patterns. For example, failures that occur rapidly in succession may suggest automated attempts.
Investigate if the failed logon occurred during non-business hours, which could indicate an unauthorized attempt when the user is unlikely to notice.
Check if the account involved in the failure has recently been subjected to password changes, account lockouts, or other modifications.
Look for other related events, such as Event ID 4740 (Account Lockout) if multiple failures led to an account being locked out.
Examine any changes to the system or network around the time of the failures, such as updates to firewall rules, security policies, or group memberships.
Use User Behavior Analytics (UBA) to identify anomalies in logon patterns for the account, particularly if the account is logging on from unexpected locations or devices.
suggestions: Investigate the source of repeated logon failures, especially if they originate from unfamiliar or external IP addresses.
Check for patterns of failed logons across multiple accounts, as this may indicate a password-spraying attack.
Set up alerts for a high volume of failed logon attempts within a short timeframe, as this could indicate a brute-force attack.
Monitor for failed logons targeting administrative or service accounts, as these are often the focus of attackers.
Cross-reference failed logon attempts with successful logons to detect potential breaches following brute-force attacks.
Review account lockout policies and thresholds to ensure they are effective against brute-force attacks.
Investigate any account lockouts related to these failed logon attempts, as they may indicate an ongoing attack.
Check for failed logon attempts during off-hours, as this could suggest an unauthorized attempt when the user is unlikely to be active.
Audit the affected accounts for any recent password changes or other suspicious activity.
Investigate related Event IDs such as 4740 (Account Lockout) to determine if multiple failures led to an account being locked out.

4634.analyst_summary: Correlate with previous logon events to ensure normal user activity. Investigate any discrepancies or unusual sequences that might suggest an account was compromised. Sudden logoff events, particularly following critical activity, should be scrutinized for signs of a manual logoff by an attacker.
detailed_analysis: Correlate the logoff event with the corresponding logon event (Event ID 4624) to verify that the session duration aligns with typical user behavior.
Examine the logon type of the original logon to determine if it was interactive, network, or remote. Remote logons (Logon Type 10) should be monitored closely for suspicious activity.
Review the logoff time to check if it occurred during non-business hours, which could indicate unauthorized access.
Analyze the account activity before the logoff to identify any unusual or critical operations that could suggest the session was hijacked.
Check for unusual patterns, such as a logoff immediately following privilege escalation (Event ID 4672) or the execution of critical commands (Event ID 4688).
Investigate if the logoff was manual or automatic (e.g., due to a system reboot or idle timeout). A sudden manual logoff could indicate an attempt to cover tracks.
Review the geographic location and source IP of the logon and logoff events to detect anomalies, such as logoffs from unexpected locations.
Correlate the logoff with other related events, such as file access or network connections, to identify data exfiltration attempts.
Examine the session duration to detect unusually short or long sessions, which may indicate automated processes or suspicious activity.
Use User Behavior Analytics (UBA) to detect deviations from normal user behavior, such as logging off immediately after logging on or after performing unusual actions.
suggestions: Investigate any logoffs that occur during non-business hours, as they could indicate unauthorized access.
Check for recent privilege escalations or account modifications that occurred before the logoff.
Correlate the logoff event with previous logon events to identify any discrepancies in session duration or behavior.
Monitor for logoffs following suspicious activities, such as access to sensitive files or execution of unusual commands.
Set up alerts for logoffs that occur immediately after logons, particularly for privileged accounts.
Investigate the source IP address and geolocation to verify if they match the user’s usual patterns.
Review network activity around the logoff time to identify potential data exfiltration or lateral movement.
Cross-reference with physical access logs, if available, to confirm that the user was present at the location when the logon and logoff occurred.
Check for concurrent logons and logoffs from the same account across different locations, as this could indicate account compromise.
Investigate related Event IDs such as 4672 (Special Privileges Assigned) or 4688 (New Process Created) to build a timeline of the user’s activities.

4648.description: A logon was attempted using explicit credentials.
4648.analyst_summary: Investigate for potential credential theft or misuse, especially when occurring in bulk. Cross-reference with known phishing campaigns or recent password changes. Failed explicit credential attempts from unexpected sources may indicate a targeted attack or lateral movement attempt.
detailed_analysis: Identify the source of the logon attempt, including the source IP address and device, to determine if the attempt came from an expected location.
Analyze the account used in the logon attempt. If the account is sensitive or privileged, this could be a sign of targeted activity.
Correlate this event with failed logon attempts (Event ID 4625) to determine if the explicit credentials were part of a brute-force attack or password-spraying attempt.
Review any recent password changes or account resets to determine if the logon attempt aligns with known user activity.
Examine the timing of the logon attempt to see if it occurred during non-business hours or outside the user’s typical work schedule.
Check if the logon attempt was part of a pattern involving multiple accounts or devices, which could indicate a coordinated attack.
Investigate the logon type used (e.g., Remote Interactive or Network) to understand the context of the attempt and assess the risk.
Cross-reference with known phishing campaigns or credential theft reports to determine if the credentials may have been compromised.
Look for any related Event IDs, such as 4624 (Successful Logon) or 4672 (Special Privileges Assigned), to identify if the attempt was followed by successful access or privilege escalation.
Use User Behavior Analytics (UBA) to detect anomalies in the user’s typical logon patterns, such as logons from new devices or locations.
suggestions: Investigate any unexpected explicit credential attempts during off-hours or from unfamiliar locations.
Correlate with failed logon attempts (Event ID 4625) to determine if this was part of a larger attack.
Cross-check with known compromised accounts from threat intelligence sources to assess if this logon was part of a wider breach.
Set up alerts for explicit credential attempts targeting privileged or sensitive accounts.
Monitor for repeated attempts using explicit credentials from the same source, as this could indicate an ongoing attack.
Investigate the account for any recent password changes, resets, or other suspicious activity.
Review associated network traffic for signs of lateral movement or data exfiltration.
Ensure that accounts targeted by failed logons have strong, unique passwords and multi-factor authentication (MFA) enabled.
Check for any successful logons following failed attempts using explicit credentials.
Investigate related Event IDs such as 4624 (Successful Logon) or 4672 (Special Privileges Assigned) to identify if the attempt led to successful access or privilege escalation.

4672.description: Special privileges assigned to a new logon.
4672.analyst_summary: Monitor for unauthorized privilege escalation attempts. Examine the context and source of the logon to identify any suspicious activity. Pay particular attention to privileged accounts used in unexpected locations or times, as these could be signs of an ongoing attack.
detailed_analysis: Identify the account that received special privileges and determine if it is commonly used for privileged activities. Accounts that rarely receive such privileges should be investigated further.
Review the source of the logon, including the IP address and device, to verify if the privileges were granted from an expected location.
Correlate with the logon type (e.g., Remote Interactive, Network) to understand the context of the privilege assignment. Remote Interactive logons with privilege escalation warrant closer scrutiny.
Investigate the timing of the privilege assignment, particularly if it occurred during non-business hours or outside of the user’s typical activity period.
Check for related logon events (Event ID 4624) and determine if the privilege assignment was followed by access to sensitive systems or data.
Analyze whether the privilege assignment was followed by any unusual account activity, such as changes to group memberships or access rights.

Review recent security alerts or incidents that may correlate with this privilege escalation, particularly if there were recent failed logon attempts (Event ID 4625) or credential misuse (Event ID 4648).
Cross-reference with changes to system configurations, security policies, or firewall rules to identify if the privilege escalation was part of a larger attack.
Examine the user’s activity history to determine if this privilege escalation is consistent with their typical role and responsibilities.
Use User Behavior Analytics (UBA) to detect anomalies in how privileges are typically assigned to this account or others within the organization.
suggestions: Investigate the source of the privilege assignment to verify if it was legitimate and necessary.
Set up alerts for privilege escalations that occur outside of normal business hours or from unexpected locations.
Review related logon events (Event ID 4624) to identify if the privilege assignment was preceded or followed by suspicious activities.
Monitor the account for further actions following the privilege assignment, such as access to sensitive files or systems.
Correlate with recent failed logon attempts (Event ID 4625) or explicit credential usage (Event ID 4648) to identify potential misuse.
Investigate any changes to group memberships or security policies associated with the privilege assignment.
Ensure that multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enforced for accounts that receive special privileges.
Audit the system and security policies to ensure that privilege assignments are properly controlled and monitored.
Check for other related Event IDs, such as 4688 (New Process Created) or 4697 (Service Installed), to detect further signs of compromise.
Investigate whether the privilege assignment aligns with any known attack patterns or tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used by adversaries.

4688.description: A new process has been created.
4688.analyst_summary: Review process creation events for suspicious or unexpected software executions. Focus on processes started by accounts with high privileges or unusual parent-child process relationships. Investigate the executable's path, hash, and any associated network connections for further anomalies.
detailed_analysis: Identify the process name, path, and executable to determine if it aligns with known, legitimate processes. Unknown or unusual processes should be investigated further.
Review the parent process that spawned the new process to understand the context. If the parent process is suspicious or unexpected, this could indicate malicious activity.
Check if the process was started by a privileged account, particularly if the process is unusual or not typically associated with that account.
Analyze the command-line arguments used when the process was started. Malicious processes often use specific arguments to hide their presence or perform malicious actions.
Correlate the process creation event with other events, such as privilege escalation (Event ID 4672) or account logon (Event ID 4624), to identify if this process is part of a larger attack.
Investigate if the process was created during non-business hours or on a system that typically does not execute such processes.
Check if the process is known to connect to external IP addresses, as this could indicate command and control (C2) communication.
Cross-reference the process executable's hash with known malware signatures to detect potential threats.
Review network activity following the process creation to detect any suspicious outbound connections.
Examine the process’s impact on system performance, as malicious processes often consume excessive resources or exhibit unusual behavior.
suggestions: Investigate processes created by privileged accounts, particularly if they occur during off-hours or from unusual locations.
Set up alerts for process creation events that match known attack patterns or use specific command-line arguments.
Audit the integrity of the process’s executable file by comparing its hash to known good values or malware databases.
Monitor for any unsigned executables or binaries not typically found in the environment, as these may indicate malicious activity.
Review parent-child process relationships for signs of process injection or other malicious techniques.
Investigate the source IP addresses or external domains contacted by the new process to detect potential command and control (C2) communication.
Ensure that processes executed on critical systems are logged and monitored for anomalies.
Cross-reference with recent security alerts or incident reports to determine if the process creation aligns with known threats.
Check for subsequent changes to system files, registry keys, or security policies following the process creation.
Investigate related Event IDs, such as 4672 (Special Privileges Assigned) or 4697 (Service Installed), to build a timeline of activities associated with this process.

Check the timing of the account creation to detect any suspicious activity.
Review recent administrative actions to validate the legitimacy of the account creation.
Analyze if the account creation occurred during off-hours or from unusual locations.
Investigate if the account creation is associated with recent security incidents.
Examine the account's initial access rights and group memberships.
Check for accounts created with non-standard naming conventions.
Review the account creation in conjunction with changes to system configurations.
Look for accounts created by service accounts or automated processes.

Review the new account's login history for unusual or unauthorized activity.
Check if this account creation coincides with any security alerts or incidents.
Ensure that all account creations follow proper authorization procedures.

Check if the account was re-enabled by a different administrator than the one who disabled it.
Analyze any activity performed by the account immediately after it was enabled.
Investigate if the account was re-enabled during non-business hours.
Correlate with other account enablement or disablement events around the same time.
Check if the account is associated with any recent security incidents.
Review group memberships assigned to the account following re-enablement.
Look for any unusual or unauthorized changes to the account’s privileges.
Examine if the account re-enablement aligns with recent job role changes.
Cross-reference with system access logs for signs of suspicious activity.
suggestions: Investigate if the account was re-enabled during non-business hours.
Cross-reference with other recent account enablement events.
Review group memberships to ensure no unauthorized access was granted.
Ensure that account enablement is properly documented and authorized.
Set up alerts for account re-enablement events outside of normal procedures.
Monitor the account closely following re-enablement for suspicious activity.
Check if the account re-enablement corresponds with recent user requests or tickets.
Audit the system for any signs of unauthorized access using the re-enabled account.
Verify that multi-factor authentication (MFA) is enforced for the account.
Review the re-enabled account’s access to critical systems and data.
